title: Standard Chartered cuts dividend after profits slump by 44%
text:
Welcome to your preview of The Times Subscribe now Standard Chartered cuts dividend after profits slump by 44% Standard Chartered profits almost halved in 12 months Philippe Lopez Katherine Griffiths Banking Editor Updated 37 minutes ago 
Standard Chartered has slashed its dividend in half after it profits slumped by 44 per cent in the first half of the year. 
Profits dropped to $1.8 billion, while revenues fell 8 per cent to $8.5 billion. As a result of the poor results, the troubled emerging markets bank cut its dividend by 50 per cent to 14.4 cents. 
Bill Winters, the new chief executive, said he had prioritised strengthening capital over returns. Standard Chartered’s core equity tier 1 ratio improved to 11.5 per cent, significantly up on its 10.7 per cent level in December 2014. 
Sir John Peace, Standard
